p.s: The given text Language learning in the UK: 'can't, won't, don't' is a newspaper article about the decline of foreign language learning in the UK by John Worne which was published on 27th January 2015 in The Telegraph.
In the following I will analyse how Worne presents his view with communicative strategies and his use of language.
At first he states what he thinks is the present situation with foreign language learning: can't, won't, don't(ll. 1-2).
He proves his thesis with the fact that the number of students to learn a foreign language has been steadily declining (ll. 3-5).
After that he states that more primary schools having their students learn a foreign language didn't change that the number still still steadily declines (ll. 6-8).
After giving these examples the author says what many people think is the solution to the problem: phones and and technological progress.
The author sees that as nonsense (ll. 12-15).
He thanthenexpresses his second thesis: that language learning is significant for the UK's position in the world (ll. 16-18).
He proves his point by mentioning that two thirds of UK's businesses need those language skills (ll. 19f).
In addition the author says that the UK's universities encourages students to learn a foreign language and that it's important to find a job (ll. 24-29).
In the end, he makes the conclusion that it is up to the parents to enable a cultural shift at home to guarantee that the UK keeps its position in the world (ll. 32-35).

The author uses a mix of parataxes and hypotaxes as well as mix of formal language (ll. 3f) ... foreign languages at the university level has been in steady decline and informal language (l. 15)Cobblers. which makes the text seem more diverse and interesting on the other hand and also accessible for a wide audience of both rather high educated people and not-so-high-educated people on the other hand.

The title makes a clear statement that the UK people don't want to learn any foreign languages which may seem controversial to many people and with that the author tries to catch the readersreader'sattention right at the beginning.
The author proves his point not only by facts and examples, but also by using many structural devices.
In line 6 languages are now on the menu he compares the menu of a restaurant with the curriculum as more foreign languages are offered at primary schools.
Within the paragraph from line 12 to 15 he uses a lot of irony.
He says that perfectly intelligent people will tell you not to worry while meaning that that is an opinion he does not share.
He also tells ironically that when trying to use ana translator on the phone one may ctash or choke on the clerk charges (l. 14).
In that whole paragraph he tells con-arguments to his own opinion so with telling that with a lot of irony the author makes the other opinions seem rediculousridiculous and wrong.

Another aspect to convince the reader is that the author uses strong words and language (e.g. (l. 27) The tough reality in a tough job market; (l. 30): There is no doubt) to make his poit more valid and convincing.
Overall, one can say that the author persuades the reader by sticking to many facts, data and examples on the onone hand; and with stylistic devices and techniques on the other hand.
In conclusion one can say that one can get easily convinced by the autorsauthor's interesting way of writing.
